Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 07:30PM - edited Jan 6, 2011 09:16PM by baf4292 I too will be starting chemo in January...not sure yet what date, but I hope it is soon...I hate the suspense of not knowing how it is going to affect me.  I am "triple negative", so even though stage is 1 and no lymph node involvement, I will be getting 4 doses of Cytoxyn and Taxotere, 3 weeks apart.  I have my own business and will continue to work throughout...hopefully my flexible schedule will make it doable.  I have mixed emotions about working...would be good to just focus on my health, but on the other hand work will also be a valuable distraction (luckily I like what I do).
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 10:01PM baf4292 wrote: Julie - I can relate to your anxiety about the re-exisions.  My lumpectomy had 1 margin that was not clear, so I went back for a re-exision and it was still not clear, so I went back for another one, which was finally clear, but barely - 1mm - 1.5mm.  My surgeon said good enough, my radiologist recommended yet another try for 2mm, my onco was neutral.  In any case the chemo at this point is more important so I don't have to make a decision yet.  Very confusing. Blindsided - Congratulations on completing your chemo!  I have same diagnosis and same chemo type, so am hoping my experience is a good as yours.  Cheered me up reading your post! I too am comforted knowing others are facing the same challenges.  We can do this.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:50PM baf4292 wrote: hsgray - too bad about the "pokes", but your description of your first chemo treatment was pretty funny...glad to see you haven't lost your sense of humor.  I, too, felt like a walking toxic waste dump for the first several days, but things are much better now (day15) aimee- I plan on getting my buzz on Sunday night, after my son's birthday dinner.  It is getting pretty messy and I feel like it is better to do it now while I feel good than wait until the next chemo dose (Thurs).  I have a lot of trepidations about it too; sort of tear-up just thinking about it, but I might as well get used to the new look since it will be part of my life for a while. I seem to be the only one on this thread taking a week of Cipro (anitbiotic) instead of the Neulasta shot.  I was warned about the SEs and my Onco thought I might not need it.  We'll see on Wed when I have my first blood test since the chemo, but my energy level has been very good after the first week, so I would be surprised if white cell count is low.  Maybe this is an alternative for me because I am not around small children like many of you and so not as likely to be exposed to germs...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 09:20PM baf4292 wrote: Annie - Thanks for the milestones...made me smile. Sounds like the concensus is that monofilament wigs are the way to go and Raquel Welch has some cute styles. I am now on day 6 of TC #2 and so far the SEs are similar to, maybe a little less than, the first time.  Defnitely not worse at least.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 09:57AM baf4292 wrote: bdavis - I first buzzed my head to about 1/4" but it felt itchy and sore especially under a hat.  My husband shaved my head and it immediately felt more comfortable.  Besides, the Taxotere makes your hair fall out unevenly and it looked really "mangey"...I think it actually looks better cleanly shaved.  tideknott - how did the hair shaving party go?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 07:44PM baf4292 wrote: I AM DONE TOO - TC#4 TODAY.  Final infusion went without incident, but it took the experienced nurse again to get it started.  They were so sweet, the nurses all signed a certificate stating that I completed my chemo.   I will definitely keep it.  Wish I felt like partying, but I am partying in my head!  Am happy to join AimeeMac, Mary Meg and Island Mom in reaching a milestone.  Have decided against further surgery, so should start 6 weeks of radiation in about 6 weeks.  I am a CPA and need to get through tax season anyway, so I am fine with the reprieve.  I think radiation will be a walk in the park compared to chemo.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 12:03PM baf4292 wrote: No one has ever mentioned my Vitamin D level to me during this whole process and I don't see it on the blood work reports I had during chemo.  Do you have to request this be tested for?  What is considered to be a "good" level of D?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 07:54PM baf4292 wrote: MaryMeg - Thanks for the interesting information re: fasting.  My brother has been a proponent of that philosophy for several years with regard to effects on aging.  I also have experienced the big temperature swings you describe, and this was probably the only SE I hadn't really expected. Anyone else receiving Cipro (an antibiotic) a week after chemo instead of the Neulasta shot?  Goal is to avoid the SEs associated with the Neulasta.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 06:51PM baf4292 wrote: I am now at day 10 after my first TC and this is the best day I have had so far.  Other than an hour and a half nap, I almost feel "normal".  I hope this continues, but too soon to tell.  For those of you wondering whether you will be able to continue working, which was a major concern of mine also, I can say that after taking off the day of the infusion and a couple of days after, I have been able to put in about 4 to 6 hours a day between working at the office and at home.  The most inconvenient thing is that after about 3 hours I get really tired and have to rest, but then I get a second wind.  I have been told that weeks 2 and 3 post-infusion get steadily better; if so I feel pretty good about keeping up with the most important things at work even though not at 100%.  Next time, however, I may plan on working on days 2, 3 because I felt the worst on days 4, 5 which is a pattern others who had been through TC on this website described. Next big hurdle is the hair thing.  A couple of days ago I felt my scalp tingling and could swear I smelled something like burning hair; but no shedding yet, so it is probably just my paranoia.  I too have the wig ready and some hats, but have a hard time imagining myself with no hair!  I am pretty sure after this experience I will never again toy with the idea of botox, facelifts or complain about a bad hair day...will just be so happy to have my hair back, imperfections and all, and be done with surgeries, treatments, etc.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 10:37PM baf4292 wrote: MaryMeg - You make us all smile!  Thanks for reminding us that there are more important things in life than Charlie Sheen! AimeeMac - I, too, will be having final #4 TC this week (Friday) and I also was told to wait a month before radiation.  There is a chance I may have to delay it longer if more surgery is in my future.  I had a lumpectomy but had to have 2 additional re-excisions because of one dirty margin, confined to DCIS.  The last one was barely acceptable (1 - 1.5mm).  Surgeon was OK with it, but radiologist thought I should try again for the 2mm they prefer.  Seems like splitting hairs to me, since it is an arbitrary measure anyway and after all isn't the radiation done to guard against local recurrance?  I was also surprised that the radiologist recommended another re-excision rather than mastectomy...I haven't heard of anyone having that many.  I asked Oncologist to be the "tie-breaker" and he said he would take it before the "tumor board".  I, too, just want to keep moving forward and get all of this treatment stuff behind me! tsunderman - My last infusion was my best experience so far and I attribute it to:  1) drank tons of water right up to and during the infusion, 2) lifted light weights and kept clinching and unclinching my fist with the arm I knew they would be using (this was a suggestion from my son, the workout guy, who felt it might help open the veins, and 3) insisted that the best nurse on the floor help the nurse assigned to me get the needle in.  Took one try, and no problems.  I really think the last factor was the most important...knowing who to ask for. Our group has made so much progress since January.  Looks like we are going to make it!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 08:29PM baf4292 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 09:54PM baf4292 wrote: I am having my first treatment of CT this Thursday also, like several others on this post.  In a wierd way I am almost looking forward to it because I am tired of trying to guess how this is going to affect me...I am ready to jump in and get it over with...I think:)  A friend who went through chemo last year suggested going to Sephora to get eyebrow stencils to help "re-draw" them if they go.  Someone on another thread had a thought I find helpful -- "you don't have to be brave, you just have to show up."
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 09:44PM baf4292 wrote: I am curious where the idea about fasting prior to chemo came from.  I was told to eat a good breakfast the day of.  Was given Emend IV prior to chemo and I really think it worked...didn't have nausea at all until day 4,5 (probably once the Emend wore off) and then it was tolerable.  Although my SEs haven't been bad, I do feel weak and since a lot of my favorite foods don't sound good, I have to force myself to keep eating.  I worry that the fasting idea will sap your much needed strength for the fight ahead.  Is fasting a medical recommendation or a personal preference? I also wonder whether to keep taking vitamins.  The onco nurse said it was "controversial" in that I guess the vitamins tend to have the opposite effect of the chemo.  But on the other hand, I don't feel like I am eating a balance diet right now (see above), just eat what I can tolerate which seems to be carbs and cheese!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 09:59PM baf4292 wrote: Amyk - I hope you stick with it...you are so close to being done and you have come this far.  Try to hang in there.  We are rooting for you! UTMom2014 - Thanks for the wig advice.  Based on your recommendation, I ordered a Raquel Welch wig from wigs.com and it arrived today.  It cost half as much and I like it twice as much as the first one I bought.  It looks just like the picture (I got the one called Boost) and feels comfortable.  I feel so much better about the whole hair thing now that I have a wig I like!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 07:37PM - edited Feb 18, 2011 07:40PM by baf4292 slct - Loved the card (I am a sucker for cats anyway) Proud Mom - Congratulations on finishing your first stage.  Soon more and more of us will be able to mark a milestone like that, and it is inspiring. AimeeMac - I had that racing mind, anxious feeling early on after diagnosis but before it was clear what I was really in for.  My husband had some relaxation tapes he was given by the hospital when he had surgery a few years ago and I found the "guided imagery" very calming.  I am not usually into that sort of approach, but the tapes were really relaxing and after about 30 minutes of listening my mind was quiet and peaceful.  Might be worth a try.  MaryMeg - If you don't mind my asking, did you receive any radiation after the mastectomy you had several years ago? JulieH - Glad to see your post, I was getting worried about you being so quiet.  Hope the nausea gets better soon.  To all of you with itchy heads -- shave it and the itch will stop; but you have to keep shaving it to stay that way.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 08:09PM baf4292 wrote: AliT - I am taking only 4 rounds of TC, and like Aimee I am triple negative...don't know if that makes a difference. I am a week out from tx#3 and am feeling better than at this point after the previous treatments.  I think it may be because they increased the pre-chemo Emend from 115 (somethings - mgs?) to 150 and I don't have that queasy feeling this time.  They said it stretches the effects of the Emend from 3 days post-chemo to 5 days.  Didn't change it just for me, but evidently for all the chemo patients at my infusion center.  JulieH - Hope you are feeling better soon.  At least the end is in sight.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 08:08PM baf4292 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 07:59PM baf4292 wrote: Proudmom - I think we all get tired of putting on the happy face sometimes.  A friend who went through this a year ago gave me a book called "Five Lessons I Didn't Learn From Breast Cancer and One Big One I Did" by Shelley Lewis and it is a darkly humourous take on this whole experience.  There is a limit to how much of the rah-rah pink ribbon approach one can tolerate, at least at this point, while we are actually living through it.  It may give you a laugh.  The single most helpful thing for me so far has been napping whenever I feel that super-tired feeling starting to take over.  I have found there is a fine line between feeling tired and feeling sick.  I force myself to lie down and think of it as giving my good-guy cells a chance to re-group to fight the bad guys.  Of course, I realize I am fortunate that I have very flexible work hours and no small children to look after. Now that the hair is almost gone, I realize that the worst thing about it is that it is a constant reminder to me and everyone around me that there is something wrong with me.  When I had my hair, on a good day I could forget about it for a while.  But now, everytime I look in the mirror I see an unfamiliar look...if only because I never wore hats before!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 07:58PM baf4292 wrote: hsgray - What a challenging experience in the hospital and all.  Its a wake-up call to the rest of us to do what we can to avoid the flu! For those of you who actually like your wig - what kind did you get and where did you find it?  Real hair, or not?  Adjustable cap or not?  Did you order it over the internet, or in person?  What is the brand?  I have one that will probably do in a pinch, but have not stopped looking for a better one...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 09:46PM baf4292 wrote: TC 2 of 4, day 14, start date Jan 6th.  Good idea Emily to "label" our treatments.  It will be interesting to see if we see a pattern.  I suspect those of you getting the AC combo are having a harder time than those of us on TC, but maybe not.  The single worst side effect I have had so far is what I now know is called "extravasation" at the infusion site...means the chemo leaked into the surrounding tissue causing swelling, redness, pain, itching and it looks gross.  Even 14 days after tx2 my right forearm is still swollen and red, but doesn't hurt anymore.  Took 12 days for my doctor to take it seriously enough to recommend some medications to help it get back to normal, and it does seem to be slowly working.  I am not thinking positive thoughts about him at the moment.  He kept  saying it was an "irritation" and it would go away on its own.  I realize now it can lead to necrosis and permanent damage in severe cases. We all seem to be hyper-aware of anyone around us with a cold!  The other day I was at the drug store and a young girl stood nearby studying the products while coughing, sneezing, wiping her nose, etc.  So I moved a couple of isles away, waiting for her to leave, when here she comes again into the shampoo aisle!  It took me about 10 minutes to shake her...ordinarily I wouldn't even notice something like that.  Renrel - thanks for the posting...I love hearing those survivor stories...helps keep us focused on why we are doing this very unpleasant, but temporary, thing!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 09:11PM - edited Jan 6, 2011 09:13PM by baf4292 My wig experience was two extremes.  The first place highly recommended by my hairdresser was a disaster.  It was a big store with mostly extensions (not too useful when you have no hair!) they only let you try on 3 wigs, the prices were reasonable, about $50 to $75 but really ugly.  Going home from that appointment was one of my lowest points in this process so far.  But I then got a referral via the infusion nurses based on the patients they see coming through.  This place required an appointment, they were kind, knowledgeable, have special products for cancer patients and will order the wig color you choose and style it.  I ordered a real hair one which cost $600 and a fake hair one which cost $300; no obligation to purchase both.  The fake hair wig looks much more like my actual hair so that is the one I got and she styled it to make it less puffy.  She also said the real hair wigs will lose some of the puffiness after several washings.  I also ordered some cute hats from Headcovers.com which arrived yesterday and I am happy with almost all of them. Had first TC treatment today and feel fine so far.  They gave me several anti nausea and allergy fighting drugs prior to the actual Chemo, so once they wear off I will have a better idea of how I am really going to feel.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 09:41PM baf4292 wrote: This is day 5 for me after first TC treatment.  First 3 days felt amazingly good.  Last 2 days more tired and a little queazy but not enough to medicate for.  Feels like the last few days of the flu or moderate morning sickness...not 100%, but functional.  My pattern has been to walk my dog every day and try to do a few things and alternate with rest.  Today I was able to work from home this way and got in about 4 hours of work.  So far I feel like the anticipation of chemo was worse than the doing of it...but I still have my hair...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 06:40PM baf4292 wrote: Hi all - Today DH buzzed my hair to about 1/4".  Since he started losing his hair in his 20's he said, :"welcome to my world."  I suspect my headcovering of choice is going to be hats, because I found some I like, I don't really know what to do with the scarves, and my wig looks better on the stand than it does on me...am going to take it back in to the wig lady next week for styling so maybe I will like it better after that.  Like everything else about this journey, the anticipation of losing my hair and trying (unsuccessfuly) to imagine what it would be like, was worse than actually biting the bullet and letting it go. I would post a picture, but seem to be the only computer-challenged participant who can't figure out how to do it.  I, too have lost about 4 - 5 lbs so far, but since I am 5'10", it isn't a major loss...actually my pants fit better :)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 08:50PM baf4292 wrote: I am now 6 weeks out from my final TC infusion.  The good news is that my taste buds are back and everything tastes great!  In fact, I have to stop myself from eating everything in sight because I appreciate the flavors so much.  The most disappointing thing for me so far is how slowly my hair is growing back .  The nurse told me before starting chemo that my hair could start to grow back within a couple of weeks of the last chemo, but here we are 6 weeks later and all I have is a stubble that could barely be described as "5 o'clock shadow".  I do think it is growing, but so much slower than I had anticipated.  However, I am grateful that about 1/2 of my eyelashes and eyebrows stayed put.  For those of you who are dismayed at the possible 15% recurrence rate even after all of this stuff we are doing, whenever that thought creeps into my mind, I immediately force myself to reverse that and remember that it also means an 85% chance that it will not come back.  When my husband was diagnosed with prostate cancer 10 years ago, he caught it early, had clean margins and was in the best possible situation and still was told there was a 10% chance it could come back.  But he preferred to focus on the 90% chance it would not, and so far that is exactly what has happened.  Everything in life has risks; we are doing everything we can to minimize ours. Congratulations to all who are finishing up.  I know that my last infusion date will always be one of the most significant dates of my life!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 10:55PM baf4292 wrote: Island Mom - I also had some problems with getting the IV started.  After the second attempt the nurse thought she had it right and I thought so too even though I could feel an aching sensation.  After all of the SE-fighting meds went in, about 10 minutes into the Taxotere I woke from my Benadryl fog to notice that the arm with the IV had swelled to about twice the size of the other arm.  Turns out the IV was not correctly positioned in the vein after all and was leaking into the surrounding tissue...uh oh.  Ninja Nurse came to the rescue in the other arm and we finally finished.  They have now labeled me a "hard stick" (doesn't sound very flattering, does it?), but hopefully that means I get the Ninja first next time and bypass the rookies.  I am beginning to see why so many of you have the ports!  But since I only have 2 TC treatments left, onco is not recommending it. ckmoma - Wow what a snow story...sounds like a nightmare.  I often think of you all in cold country trying to get to all of these appointments under such trying conditions.  Favorite head covering so far - my black suede Ugg hat with an upside-down tulip shape, lined in black fur...the most expensive hat I have bought, but also the least "cancer-patient-looking".  Second favorite - velvet newsboy cap from headcovers.com.  Without the Neulasta shot my wbc was an excellent 10 before tx#2, so I am pretty content to continue with the antibiotics during the second week instead.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 08:23PM baf4292 wrote: UTMom - I, too would love to hear the scientific explanation for why, while hair on your head starts to come back, eyelashes and eyebrows continue to fall out.  I don't get it. bdavis - wow, you have a lot on your plate.  I do think that once you have made up your mind about the surgery you will feel better...indecision is a big cause of stress.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 09:57PM baf4292 wrote: slcst - You are right about not needing the onco score because you are triple negative.  I asked my onco what it is for and he said it is to measure how much your chances of survival increase by going through chemo,  But for us TNs who are also usually grade 3, they already know it makes a big difference so they don't need to bother with it. Got to go drink more water because tomorrow is Day #1 for me.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 06:08PM baf4292 wrote: vis0121 - Did they give you any Emend via the IV before the chemo?  If not, see if you can request it next time.  I think almost everyone on here so far who has had it has had tolerable nausea.  My onco offered it as an option and because of the posts I had seen here I said definitely do it.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 06:04PM baf4292 wrote: Aimeemac - looks like we are on the same schedule of TC.  My first treatment was on the 6th and the next is also the 27th.  Today for the first time I also noticed hair starting to fall out, so it won't be long now.  I have felt almost "normal" since last Saturday (day 10), which I am thankful for. My thoughts are with all of you ladies who are struggling with the SEs.  It is interesting how different the reactions are to the same treatments...but everyone on this thread is well aware that life is not necessarily fair.  Hang in there!  I am really appreciating this group...makes me feel not so alone in this.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 29, 2011 09:51AM baf4292 wrote: sherryhuttrs - I had the same sequence you describe before my lumpectomy and did not find it difficult or painful at all.  There was a slight stinging sensation when they inject the dye and I remember the mammogram/wire step required a few tries to get it right, but compared to chemo I thought it was pretty easy.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2011 04:13PM baf4292 wrote: I am 3 months PFC (had TC) and here is my progression so far:  Looked like an alien (ie. bald) for about 6 - 7 weeks; then looked like a concentration camp survivor for another month or so; now have a hair style similar to Barack Obama's!  I am not complaining...at least I see progress, but none of these looks are the real "me" yet!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 09:44PM baf4292 wrote: GuyGirl - Your post is the first I have heard that using Rogaine and then stopping it is related to the hair to falling out.  I am using Minoxidil 2x a day which is the Walgreen's version (I think Lago recommended it) and I think it is helping, but hard to say since maybe enough time just passed and  my hair has started to grow naturally.  But it is still only about 1/16" and I am now 8 weeks out from last chemo.  Where did you hear that about the Rogaine?  Anyone else have any experience with Rogaine/Minoxidil? My eyebrows and eyelashes continue to drop off a few each day.  Has anyone tried false eyelashes, especially for special occasions?
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 11:23PM baf4292 wrote: Rachel and Saramom - Love the pictures; am so jealous of your beautiful hair.  I remember when I would have thought of you as having short hair, but now it looks soooo long to me! Christine - When my hair started coming in it also looked first like light-colored peach fuzz, followed  by a prickly kind of stuble (darker, like my real hair color), which when it grew a little longer now feels like fur.  All this to say, it sounds to me like you are seeing the first stages of hair growth.  I couldn't see real progress until about 6 1/2 to 7 weeks post chemo.  Maddeningly slow I know.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 11:13PM baf4292 wrote: My last boost was scheduled for last Friday and I got a call on Thursday telling me the machine was down, so I "could have a nice 3 day weekend".  I replied that ordinarily that would be great, but Friday would be #36 of 36 treatments and so the thought of delaying the finish line until next Monday was not so thrilling.  (Isn't that typical of this BC experience...you think the plan is X and then "not so fast there lady, you have this detour to make first").  The nice tech at the rad center said she would see if they could locate another machine for me, which they did at another location and I am so happy to report I am really, really done!  I found rads much easier than chemo, but I have non-fragile skin that held up well.  The fatigue hit at about week 20 and I still have to monitor it, but find it tolerable with well-timed naps.  Like Ton Lee, I now have a sort of abandoned feeling though, as my Rads doc has been on vacation for the last 3 weeks and I was told I would be seeing her next 6 weeks after treatment ended.  No one has mentioned how the post-treatment monitoring will go...mammogram frequency, possible MRIs, etc.  My general practitioner referred me originally to the surgeon who in turn referred me to the Onc and the Radiologist...not clear to me who is in charge now that all of the treatment phases are completed...me?
Posts.Title: May 2011 Radiation Pinkprincess GabbyCal

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 09:23PM baf4292 wrote: The radiation gal suggested I get a bra extender that hooks on the back and makes it looser.  This has worked well for me, especially since my regular bra is not an underwire-type. I have now completed about 12 of 33 treatments and am now starting to feel the fatigue, but like Romansma I am not sure if it is from just the radiation or the cumulative effects of surgery/chemo/radiation.  I feel like I have been tired off and on since October when this all started for me.
Posts.Title: May 2011 Radiation Pinkprincess GabbyCal

Posts.Content: May 18, 2011 09:03PM baf4292 wrote: ftblmom3 - You guessed right...in spite of being stage 1 and all clear nodes, the triple negative/grade 3 part trumps everything else with respect to chemo.  tinaj - I have felt the same way about the little tugs they give you before saying "perfect"...doesn't seem very exact!
Posts.Title: May 2011 Radiation Pinkprincess GabbyCal

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 11:36PM baf4292 wrote: GabbyCal - I am hungrier than usual too.  Wish I could say it is just for "good" food, but actually it is for all food. They did the simulation for my boosters recently and I can see that, unlike the regular radiation treatments, the boosters will be aiming straight down at my heart.  When I asked how they "block" the radiation from affecting heart/lungs, they said the booster rays basically don't go in as far and are less intense.  Hmmm...sounds a lot like they are saying "trust me" that they can control this stuff.
Posts.Title: May 2011 Radiation Pinkprincess GabbyCal

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 12:19AM baf4292 wrote: I start rads on April 27th...not sure for how many weeks yet. I am assuming the fatigue associated with radiation will not be as bad as chemo, but I am tired of feeling tired!  Will be following you ladies on this thread to see how you are doing.
Posts.Title: May 2011 Radiation Pinkprincess GabbyCal

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 11:51PM baf4292 wrote: Laura 53 - Don't know how predictive this is, but after 3 treatments I can say I feel really fine and drive myself back to work with no problems.  Pixelsupply - Thanks for the product information...my radiation center didn't recommend anything but aloe vera. "Hi" to the other January chemo ladies - aren't you glad to be on this thread now?! I actually feel like the "young, healthy one" in the radiation waiting room...some of the other folks look pretty ill...
